Award.AwardTitle: New GK-12: Reach for the Stars: Computational Models for Teaching and Learning in Physics, Astronomy and Computer Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Developed around the research theme of computer innovation in modeling and simulation of complex human and physical systems, co-PIs and their students will work with local classroom teachers with the goal of taking cutting-edge modeling and simulation from the fields of computer science, physics and astronomy and translate them into tools that can teach grade-level appropriate science content. Each graduate fellow will be partnered with a local classroom teacher and will engage in a training, development, and implementation process over the entire year. External evaluators will help us assess progress towards the goals and benchmarks of the program.

More broadly, this work will build the graduate fellow?s teaching, analytical and communication skills. The fellows will gain a deeper understanding of the foundations of their research in deconstructing and isolating the basic concepts of computer science, physics, and astronomy from their work to teach them to the classroom students. Classroom teachers will be exposed to cutting-edge scientific research and the research process as well as forming lasting partnerships with university researchers and scientists. Classroom students, many from traditionally underrepresented populations, will gain an improved understanding of science content and the research process, enabling them to be more informed consumers of science content presented in the media. Classroom students will also be encouraged to pursue careers in science, technology, mathematics and engineering from interactions with the fellows as role models and mentors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Reach for the Stars: Computational Models for Teaching and Learning in Physics, Astronomy and Computer Science is a program funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF), with support from the Center for Interdisciplinary Exploration and Research in Astrophysics (CIERA) and Northwestern University. This NSF Graduate Students in K-12 Education (GK12) program places science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) graduate student fellows in 6th – 12th grade math and science classrooms for the academic year with the goal of enriching their education and strengthening their development as researchers by advancing their communication and teaching skills. The fellows work in partnership with a collaborating teacher to bring more inquiry-based teaching methods into the classroom and to further expose middle and high school teachers and students to the research process. From June 2010 through May 2016, Reach for the Stars worked with 34 different graduate students, 31 classroom teachers at 16 different schools. During this time lesson plans were developed and introduced to over 4,000 middle and high school students. These lessons are still utilized in the classrooms today, introducing computational thinking and modeling to more and more students each year. The lessons are freely available and can be found at http://gk12.ciera.northwestern.edu/classroom/lessonplans.html.

Teachers selected for the program have come from schools in Evanston, Chicago, Skokie, and other communities close to the Northwestern campus. They benefit from the presence of a “resident scientist” in their classrooms, giving their students exposure to practicing scientists and engineers. Participating teachers and graduate students have commented on the value of the program:

“Most professional development opportunities for teachers involve 1-3 day conferences of mostly talking heads presenting the latest fads in education--some useful, some not. Mostly, what these PD's lack is an opportunity to build personal, professional, and institutional relationships over time with a lasting impact on teachers, researchers, students, and coordinators. Reach for the Stars does just this. It allows teachers at different stages in their careers and from a variety of backgrounds to connect with some of the best up and coming scientific minds at one of the top research institution in the world and build relationships that provide excellent outreach to students who are inspired to pursue scientific studies and careers. It also allows teachers practical training and experience in current research, improving their craft not only through knowledge gained and methodology in the form of computational thinking and mathematical modeling as presented by outstanding graduate students, it also gives the teacher a different pedagogical perspective in helping the graduate student present lesson to high school students. The synergistic benefits to all involved cannot be overstated, and the parallels to other national movements in education, from common core to NGSS, fit perfectly with the program design and practice. For me, it was one of the most powerful professional development opportunities I have experienced in my 23 years as a teacher, and I still remain in touch with my graduate fellow and still use the lessons that we developed. It also afforded me the opportunity to extend the connection as I have put him in touch with a current student who is interested in pursuing the same line of research. Compared to sitting at a conference and taking notes, the astronomical difference is obvious!”

John Kretsos, Science Instructor Niles North High School
